newsitem.title: THAILAND: Bkk of Commerce tumbles on delisting fear.
newsitem.headline: Bkk of Commerce tumbles on delisting fear.

text.p: Shares of troubled Bangkok Bank of Commerce were heavily sold off on Thursday on investor concerns about possible delisting of the bank after it posted huge losses last year, brokers said.
At 0440 GMT, Bangkok Bank of Commerce slid 11.90 baht to 4.10 and was the most actively traded issue in volume worth 175 million baht.

"Most investors tried to cut losses on the share after its prolonged suspension. Worries about possible delisting of the bank in future also prompted investors to get out of its shares," said one broker at Ekachart Finance and Securities.
BBC shares resumed trade on the Stock Exchange of Thailand on Thursday after an 11-month suspension.
The SET said last Friday that BBC's deteriorating financial position made it a candidate for delisting.

The exchange said in compliance with its regulations, it would give bank shareholders and investors a chance to trade Bangkok Bank of Commerce shares between April 17 and May 16 before it decides whether to delist the bank. From May 19, the shares would be suspended again.
The bank last week revised net losses for 1996 to a hefty 24.85 billion baht ($955.8 million) after the central bank instructed it to raise provisions for doubtful and non-performing loans.
The 1996 results were revised from a previously announced unaudited 1996 net loss of 2.84 billion baht.
The government took over the ailing bank in May 1996 to save it from a massive run on its deposits after it was found saddled with big debts.

The central bank has asked the Industrial Finance Corp of Thailand to manage the ailing bank for seven years. The industrial financing bank has been given an option to initially buy an 18 percent equity stake in the bank.
